awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Emergent Mechanics of Randomly Packed Elastic Filaments
awd_abstract_narration:
When a cardinal builds her iconic cup-nest, she uses her own body as template and molds thin twigs, grass strands, and bark strips into a structure that, despite its softness, reliably holds its shape against various mechanical perturbations. This naturally-selected engineering solution is the result of a subtle interplay between geometry, elasticity, and friction that has not yet been characterized or modeled despite its potential in building, packaging, self-repairing, shock-absorption, and material reusability. The 'bird nest', if defined as a random packing of slender, elastic elements, is an unusual material: it is cohesive without attractive interactions; it is collectively soft and plastic while its elements are hard and elastic.  Through coordinated physical and computational experiments, this collaborative project will advance the science of soft granular materials by relating bulk mechanical properties of idealized 'nest systems' with variations in constituents' properties and geometry. Results will generate new knowledge in granular physics, and will appeal to emerging aleatory architecture and engineering paradigms. Indeed, the ability to build through impermanent contacts and design lightweight materials with prescriptive mechanical properties cuts through many areas of high current importance: civil engineering and architectures (reliable, inexpensive, reusable and self-repairing materials), transportation (lightweight composites, shock absorbers), advanced manufacturing. This is in line with the national need of increasing industry competitiveness, which advances the national health, prosperity, and welfare; and secures the national defense. The project also promises to capture the imagination of a broad audience by creating an unusual bridge between relatable protagonists (birds) and often inaccessible fields of physics and engineering. Additionally, STEM outreach activities will be conducted at individual institutions to attract middle school students and female students, respectively, towards science and engineering. Undergraduate students will also be offered positions in either group for exposure to advance engineering research.

With increasing aspect ratio, the mechanical behavior of disordered granular packings changes. Where applied stresses distribute in chains of 1D contacts for spheroids, slenderness introduces bending moments and long-range interaction. Impermanent frictional contacts set the system apart from semi-flexible polymer networks and other non-woven materials which derive mechanical response from permanent crosslinks. Experimental evidence from disordered, randomly packed, elastic fibers or filaments based structures, such as the bird nests, suggest that these material systems exhibit frequency-dependent elastoplastic behavior, finite tensile response, and enhanced specific strength.  In the absence of a theoretical framework and strictly applicable principles of statistical mechanics, an experimental platform for the benchmarking and physical characterization of these materials will be developed in this project.  These will be complemented by a high fidelity computational counterpart to direct a search for novel mechanical states and transitions. The project will provide insights into the relationship between macroscopic and microscopic mechanics of bird nest-like systems, paving the way towards prescriptive design of novel materials.  Moreover, it will spur new directions in granular physics theory and explain a functional mechanism from a naturally-selected engineered structure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Motivation
The project is inspired by the engineering strategy of cup nest building birds, which pack together semiflexible filaments to make multifunctional, cohesive structures with no adhesive material.  To derive abstract design principle, we simplify the system to that of synthetic, nest-like analogs made of straight, flexible rods and probe their behaviors with table-top experiments, specifying constituent element properties and analyzing the geometry and mechanics of the resulting aggregates.  Our intention is to find: generic relationships between bulk mechanical properties and properties of the constituent elements, such as to facilitate exploration of tunable materials within our simplified parameter space; micromechanical explanations for phenomena observed in our simplified system, which likely apply to other materials composed of and governed by fundamentally similar elements and interactions; and a characterization framework amenable to benchmarking computational experiments, such that simulation can be used to further explore experimentally less accessible parts of parameter space for exotic or functional mechanical behavior.
Results
Packing statistics:  The first experimental results confirmed previous theory and data concerning the packing statistics of rods of varying aspect ratio, and demonstrated that boundary or finite-size effects, or packing protocol do not distinguish our system from the general case.  Volume fraction, measured by automated image analysis, over many vertical excitations displayed the expected asymptotic approach to robust values consistent with previous theory for large aspect ratio.
Primary features of mechanical response: We focused analysis of our system on two responses when crushed uniaxially with fixed walls:  the existence of steady-state stress-strain cycles in which energy dissipation approaches a constant value independent of strain rate; and a non-linear stiffness (maximum stress/ maximum strain) for a given steady state cycle.  The former appeared to be common to granular materials, but yet unexplained mechanistically, and the latter characterizes a non-linear stiffness that may be related to constituent properties.
CT Analysis: Computer-assisted tomographical images of packing samples were used to extract quantities of concern for understanding micromechanics.  Segmentation of CT data from experimental samples was achieved by analyzing successive 2D slices, extracting spatial distributions of occupied volume, contacts, and orientation of filament segments.  Resulting data was used to validate simulations, and its documentation promises to be of value for other researchers similarly analyzing mechanics of granular materials.
Simulation Validation: Computational analogs developed by our collaborators complimented our experiments with detailed information about the physical states of every constituent element in a packing.  To benefit from this strategy, simulations were tuned and validated by experimental data.  Within the constraints of computational power and time, we found a range of accessible parameters and built a data set in which to compare both bulk mechanical responses and statistics such as packing fraction, filament orientation, and contact distributions.  The bulk mechanical behavior, defined by the effective stiffness and dissipated energy was found to qualitatively agree for a range of input parameters.
Micromechanical analysis: Leveraging the experimentally validated simulations, an underlying mechanism to explain the bulk behavior was found by monitoring position and motion of contacts during cycles.  The formation and deletion of transient contacts was related to the observed non-linear stiffness, and the asymmetric motion of those contacts between instroke and outstroke was associated with the observed hysteretic energy loss over cyclic compression.
CURRENT AND FUTURE
Boundary effects and screening:  Following a recently published method to extrapolate the statistics of large fibrous packings in which the boundaries play negligible role, we are extrapolating the mechanical response to the continuum limit by varying height and diameter of the boundaries and recording trends in the stiffness and hysteresis.
Transitional behavior with increasing aspect ratio:  A subset of the experimental samples for which we scale the filament length to the overall height and diameter of the cylinder, at sizes accessible to simulation will reveal the mode in which energy is stored during compression.  We expect there to be a tradeoff in the portion stored in Hertzian contacts vs. bending modes, which would accompany the transition between being `granular' to `fibrous'.  Initial data suggests a point where we can expect to find sharp changes in behavior, and therefore where to look in micromechanical quantities from simulation.
Dynamic Uniaxial Compression:  We have developed a method to probe the dynamic response of the aggregates using automated image analysis and electromagnetic shaker.  By measuring the absolute and relative motions of a vertically oscillating cylinder containing the sample and a weighted top disk, we can extract both stress and strain over time.  Preliminary data showed an unexpected richness in response over varying frequencies, but further analysis will be required to separate inertial effects.
